org.mockito
Class CustomMatcher<T>

java.lang.Object
  org.mockito.CustomMatcher<T>
Type Parameters:
T -
All Implemented Interfaces:
ArgumentMatcher<T>
public abstract class CustomMatcher<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements ArgumentMatcher<T>

Allows creating customized argument matchers.

See Matchers Use one of the Matchers.argThat(org.mockito.CustomMatcher), Matchers.intThat(org.mockito.CustomMatcher), etc. methods and implement your own CustomMatcher, e.g: 

   class IsListOfTwoElements extends CustomMatcher<List> {
      public boolean matches(List list) {
          return list.size() == 2;
      }
   }
   
   List mock = mock(List.class);
   
   stub(mock.addAll(argThat(new IsListOfTwoElements()))).toReturn(true);
   
   mock.addAll(Arrays.asList("one", "two"));
   
   verify(mock).addAll(argThat(new IsListOfTwoElements()));
Custom matchers are generally used very rarely.

To keep it readable you may want to extract method, e.g: 

   stub(mock.addAll(argThat(new IsListOfTwoElements()))).toReturn(true);
   //becomes
   stub(mock.addAll(listOfTwoElements()).toReturn(true);

Method Detail

appendTo

public void appendTo(java.lang.StringBuilder builder)
Description copied from interface: ArgumentMatcher
Appends a string representation of this matcher to the given builder. In case of failure, the printed message will show this string to allow to know which matcher was used for the failing call.

Specified by:
appendTo in interface ArgumentMatcher<T>
Parameters:
builder - the builder to which the string representation is appended.

matches

public abstract boolean matches(T argument)
Description copied from interface: ArgumentMatcher
Returns whether this matcher accepts the given argument.

Like Object.equals(), it should be aware that the argument passed might be null and of any type. So you will usually start the method with an instanceof and/or null check.

The method should never assert if the argument doesn't match. It should only return false.

Specified by:
matches in interface ArgumentMatcher<T>
Parameters:
argument - the argument
Returns:
whether this matcher accepts the given argument.
